subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Atlas Iron (AGO AT) board determined Hancock offer could lead to superior proposal than offer from Mineral Resources; Fujifilm (4901 JT) sues Xerox (XRX) for over USD 1bln
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP (AMP AT)
- Co. is to boost spending on consultants to speed up remediation programming after it acknowledged it was taking too long in compensating customers. (AFR)

APA Group (APA AT)
- Co. is said to expect a consortium of Canadian pension funds to rival offer made by CK Infrastructure (1038 HK). (Newswires)

Atlas Iron (AGO AT)
- Co. board said it determined that Hancock offer could lead to superior proposal than offer from Mineral Resources (MIN AT) and that the latter has 3 days to make a counter-offer. (Newswires)

Insurance Australia Group (IAG AT)
- Co. is to sell Thai and Indonesia units to Tokio Marine (8766 JT) for JPY 40bln. (Nikkei)

Other News
- The Senate vote regarding AUD 144bln in income tax reductions is said to have descended into a game of chicken, with the federal government vowing to remain firm and not split its package, while Labor is only willing to support the initial phase of the plan. Reports added unless the government can persuade One Nation and the two Centre Alliance senators to support all three stages of the tax plan, it must either give way and split the package so the first phase of the tax cuts can be rolled out on July 1st or shelve the plan for a later attempt. (AFR)

Energy
- WTI crude futures settled higher by 1.2% after it rebounded and reclaimed the USD 65.00/bbl level. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Fujifilm (4901 JT)
- Co. sues Xerox (XRX) for over USD 1bln due to breach of contract in the termination of their merger after the US firm succumbed to pressure from activist investors Icahn and Deason. (Nikkei)

Suzuki (7269 JT)
- Co. is said to plan to end partnership with Changan. (Newswires)

Tokio Marine (8766 JT)
- Co. is to acquire Insurance Australia Group (IAG AT) Thai and Indonesia units. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. is to reorganise its overseas business including establishing regional headquarters for North America, Europe and India. (Newswires)

Korean Air Lines (003490 KS)
- Prosecutors seeking arrest warrant for the wife of Co. CEO regarding alleged illegal hiring. (Newswires)

SK Telecom (017670 KS)
- Police are said to seek an arrest warrant for Co. CEO Hwang on alleged involvement in illegal donations to lawmakers. (Newswires)

Woori Bank (000030 KS)
- Co. is hoping to be approved for holding company structure. (Newswires)

Telecoms
- SK Telecom (017670 KS) and KT Corp. (030200 KS) secured 100MHz each in the 3.5GHz 5G spectrum auction while LG Uplus (032640 KS) gets 800MHz. (Yonhap)

Geopolitical
- US and South Korea agree to postpone joint military exercises which were set for August. (Yonhap)

Other News
- Government approves selling stake in STX Engine to UAMCO. (Newswires)

Data Recap
- South Korean Export Price Index (May) Y/Y 0.1% (Prev. -2.0%). (Newswires)
- South Korean Import Price Index (May) Y/Y 8.1% (Prev. 4.0%)

subject: US President Trump says has asked US Trade Representative to identify USD 200bln in Chinese goods for further tariffs of 10%
content: - US President Trump says the tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods will be imposed if China goes through with its USD 50bln retaliation threat, while he also states that China raising tariffs is unacceptable.
reaction_details:
- USD/JPY immediately moved lower from 9 pips to 110.42 from 110.51 and fell to 110.32 in the 5 mins after the news.
- Emini S&P fell 10 points to 2767 from 2777 during the 5 mins after the release.

content:
AISA-PAC

South Korean Export Price Index (May) Y/Y 0.1% (Prev. -2.0%). (Newswires)
South Korean Import Price Index (May) Y/Y 8.1% (Prev. 4.0%)
 

UK

UK government has been defeated as expected in House of Lords concerning plans to give lawmakers a ‘Meaningful Vote’ in the final Brexit deal. (Newswires)

Brexit deal is unlikely until the end of the year due to continue deadlock between the UK and the EU on Irish border, according to reports. (FT)


EU

German Chancellor Merkel said Germany will not let in migrants that have already been registered in other countries and that she has been assured of support for seeking bilateral agreements ahead of the end-June EU summit. (Newswires)

Germany’s CSU party leader Seehofer hopes that Chancellor Merkel can reach agreement with the EU on migration in June and warned that if not, Germany has to be prepared to turn people away at the border. Furthermore, Seehofer added that no one wants to end German government coalition nor a break up the CDU/CSU parliamentary bloc. (Newswires)

ECB's Vasiliauskas (Hawk) said the decision on interest rate change can be expected towards Autumn next year. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Ecuador's oil minister said OPEC is to discuss oil production increase, while he added that Saudi Arabia and Russia want to release some production and that OPEC has a proposal to increase output by 1.5mln BPD. (Newswires)

UAE energy minister said significant progress that OPEC+ made can only be sustained if cooperation is institutional in some way. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US and South Korea agree to postpone joint military exercises which were set for August. (Yonhap)
 

US

Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawk) said US growth and labour market are strong, while he also commented that inflation is near target. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bostic (Voter, Dove) said Fed is comfortable with continuing to raise rates towards the neutral level, but added he is not sure how many more hikes it will take to get there. Bostic also said he still sees three hikes this year for a base case and warned about being cavalier about possible yield inversion. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

Intel (INTC) was lower following a downgrade at Northland, which predicts a decline in server growth in Q3 and sees no clear catalyst for the chipmaker following its last earnings report; Northland sees more competition from Advanced Macro Devices (AMD). Biogen was hit following PTC Therapeutics’ (PTCT) positive results from its muscular atrophy data, where STAT’s Adam Feuerstein reported it may be a threat to Biogen (BIIB) which hit stock by ~6% and was at the bottom of the Nasdaq for Monday’s session. On the flipside, China’s JD.com (JD) was higher following a $550mln investment from Alphabet’s (GOOGL) Google as part of a strategic partnership. CVX outperformed in the DJI as it is to reduce costs by looking to introduce shared pipelines in its new $88bln Gorgon and Wheatstone LNG plants in Australia, also the energy giant benefitted from Monday’s higher oil prices, as did Range Resources (RRC) despite being replaced by Broadridge (BR) in the S&P500 at the open today. SPX -0.21%, NASDAQ COMP +0.01%, DJI -0.41%.

Treasuries were little changed, and traded relatively rangebound on Monday, though some downside pressure was seen across the complex in afternoon trade as the dollar weakened moderately, and as equities recovered some of the losses seen previously after China retaliated to US tariffs. Bumper issuance from Bayer added downside pressure to the complex, launching an 8-part USD 15bln to finance the acquisition of Monsanto. Volumes were generally thin, and at settlement, major curve spreads were little changed. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) unchanged at 119-19.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries flat, DXY down, Crude up.
  • REAR-VIEW: ECB Sintra conference begins, Fed’s Bostic repeats 3 hikes view.
  • AHEAD: RBA Minutes overnight; US Housing Starts & Building permits; Hungary rate decision; ECB speak from Sintra (Draghi, Praet, Lane & Liikanen); Fedspeak (Bullard); API inventories.

 

  • * FED SPEAK: Fed’s Bostic (Voter, Dovish) still sees three 2018 hikes as his base case. He added that he is comfortable with rates rising towards the neutral level, but he is unsure how many more hikes it will take to get o neutral (NOTE: previous to last week’s FOMC, estimated that was between 2.25-2.75%). Bostic noted neither wages nor inflation seem to be heading for an unsustainable increase, with the latter likely to remain around the target of 2%. He noted the economy is in a pretty good place, but he feels the recent strength is due to temporary factors and is not a major shift in momentum. Business optimism is being affected by trade and tariff concerns. He warned about being cavalier over a possible yield inversion and stated a press conference after every policy meeting a good thing.

* ECB SPEAK: ECB's Vasiliauskas (Hawkish) noted risks to the Euro-area economy are balanced, and said the decision on interest rate change can be expected towards Autumn next year (in line with the ECB’s guidance).

* GEOPOLITICS: North Korean leader is to arrive in Beijing as early as Tuesday for his third meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

* DATA: The NAHB Housing Market Index for June came in at 68, 2 points below the recent average and consensus of 70. Economic growth is expected to keep demand strong though buyers face affordability struggles, Wells Fargo said, adding that the fall in the index was largely due to higher lumber prices.

* SPX -0.21%, NASDAQ COMP -0.06%, DJI -0.41%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -1.48%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.16%, Energy: +1.13%, Financials: -0.07%, Health Care: -0.98%, Industrials: -0.38%, Materials: -0.26%, Telecoms: -1.97%, Tech: +0.26%, Utilities: +0.35%.

Intel (INTC) was lower following a downgrade at Northland, which predicts a decline in server growth in Q3 and sees no clear catalyst for the chipmaker following its last earnings report; Northland sees more competition from Advanced Macro Devices (AMD). Biogen was hit following PTC Therapeutics’ (PTCT) positive results from its muscular atrophy data, where STAT’s Adam Feuerstein reported it may be a threat to Biogen (BIIB) which hit stock by ~6% and was at the bottom of the Nasdaq for Monday’s session. On the flipside, China’s JD.com (JD) was higher following a $550mln investment from Alphabet’s (GOOGL) Google as part of a strategic partnership. CVX outperformed in the DJI as it is to reduce costs by looking to introduce shared pipelines in its new $88bln Gorgon and Wheatstone LNG plants in Australia, also the energy giant benefitted from Monday’s higher oil prices, as did Range Resources (RRC) despite being replaced by Broadridge (BR) in the S&P500 at the open today.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) UNCHANGED AT 119-19. Treasuries were little changed, and traded relatively rangebound on Monday, though some downside pressure was seen across the complex in afternoon trade as the dollar weakened moderately, and as equities recovered some of the losses seen previously after China retaliated to US tariffs. Bumper issuance from Bayer added downside pressure to the complex, launching an 8-part USD 15bln to finance the acquisition of Monsanto. Volumes were generally thin, and at settlement, major curve spreads were little changed.

* WTI FUTURES (N8) SETTLE 79 CENTS HIGHER AT $65.85/BBL; BRENT (Q8) FUTURES SETTLE $1.90 HIGHER AT $75.34/BBL. Ahead of the series of OPEC/OPEC+ meetings this week, the groups are to discuss relaxing output as to add between 300k BPD to 600k BPD of supply to the market, sources reported on Monday. The amount looks to be a compromise from the 1.5mln BPD that Russia has argued for in recent weeks, likely to appease the likes of Iran, Iraq and Venezuela, who are happy with the status quo – there were reports over the weekend that the three will veto any OPEC decision to lift output by that magnitude (OPEC require unanimous decision in order to change their output quotas). UAE’s oil minister on Monday said the global oil market is close to rebalancing; Ecuador’s oil minister also delivered comments on Monday, stating that OPEC is to discuss oil production increase by 1.5mln BPD. According to UBS’ calculations, 400k BPD supply rise will likely be needed to offset declines in Venezuelan production in H2 2018, and this estimate could be subject to upward revisions if Iranian exports begin to slip in response to US sanctions on the nation. And on Monday, there was a reminder that the fragile geopolitical situation in Libya could add to supply outages, with Libyan production shut-ins to rise to 400k BPD is the oil port shutdowns continue, according to the NOC (note: supply disruptions currently stand at 240k BPD, according to PVM). Elsewhere, there are continued signs that the Saudis are nudging exports up: JODI data on Monday reported Saudi exports rose by 190k MM to 7.312mln BPD in April. Elsewhere, according to EIA data, US total shale regions oil production (July) is seen higher by 141k BPD at 7.34mln BPD (June expected a 128k BPD rise). Ahead of tomorrow’s API, the latest Reuters poll finds analysts expect headline crude stocks to draw by 2.7mln this week, distillates are seen drawing by 0.4mln and gasoline by 0.5mln.

* DXY: An early attempt to retest 95.000+ highs fell just shy of last Friday’s new 2018 high, and the index subsequently faded to circa 94.700 before stabilising again. US-China trade wars are back to the fore after reciprocal $50bln tariffs, but this only partially undermined the Dollar alongside rebounds in certain rival currencies.

* GBP: A G10 underperformer through most of Monday’s session amidst niggling Brexit uncertainty ahead of parliament votes on amendments to amendments of the EU withdrawal bill that were rejected last week, and in the run up to Thursday’s BoE policy calls that could arguably be more dovish/less hawkish than the ECB last week. Cable meandered between 1.3225-85 and EURGBP from 0.8730-80 as a result.

* CHF, JPY: The Franc was a gradual gainer and just eclipsed its safe-haven peer as it rebounded a bit further from parity vs the USD and 1.1600 vs the EUR on renewed safe-haven demand as Germany’s ruling coalition continued to discuss the contentious immigration issue and the CSU set an end of June deadline to Merkel’s CDU to come up with a mutually acceptable resolution. Meanwhile, USDJPY continued to trade either side of 110.50, and mainly lower as the day wore on and Greenback lost its initial momentum.

* EUR, CAD, NZD, AUD: All losinf moderately vs the USD as the single currency recovered to reclaim 1.1600, while the USDCAD defended 1.3200, with the aid of a rebound in oil prices. Looking down under, the Kiwi and AUD were both very constrained around 0.6950 and just over 0.7400 respectively.

* EM: More pain for the likes of the Lira, Peso, Rand and Real on a combination of negative/bearish factors and regardless of concerted attempts to draw lines in the sand via daily intervention and some new moves/initiatives aimed at curbing local currency depreciation. On that note, Turkish President Erdogan issued a plea for citizens to exchange USDs and Euros into TRY.

subject: ECB's Draghi makes no monetary policy remarks in his introductory comments
UBS Weekly FX Flows: EUR reversed 10-week selling streak
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD registered substantial inflows as strong buying by asset managers and private clients outweighed selling by hedge funds and corporates.
  • USDJPY, EURJPY: USDJPY saw marginal inflows as hedge fund buying slightly exceeded selling by all other clients. EURJPY was net sold for a fifth straight week, led mostly by asset managers while other client groups showed limited directionality.
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD was net bought, as hedge fund selling was more than offset by buying from all other clients. GBP saw marginal outflows vs EUR on the back of corporate and hedge fund selling while asset managers and private clients demonstrated buying interest.
  • EURCHF, USDCHF: CHF saw inflows vs EUR for the first time in five weeks, as buying by asset managers and private clients dominated selling by corporates and hedge funds. USDCHF saw outflows as selling by corporates and asset managers outweighed buying by hedge funds and private clients.
  • AUDUSD, NZDUSD, and USDCAD: AUDUSD experienced outflows as heavy hedge fund selling outweighed buying by all other clients. NZDUSD saw marginal inflows, driven by hedge fund buying interest, while asset managers sold the pair. USDCAD saw inflows as asset manager and hedge fund buying outweighed selling from private and corporate clients.
  • EURSEK, EURNOK, USDSEK, and USDNOK: EURSEK and EURNOK saw strong inflows as all client groups, led by asset managers, showed buying interest for both pairs. USDSEK recorded inflows as buying by asset managers exceeded selling by hedge funds and private clients while corporates showed limited directionality. NOK registered inflows vs USD; all client groups bought NOK except for private clients whose flows were more or less flat.

  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) – The oil group is looking to import liquefied natural gas in Australia to fight the 2021 shortage. Separately, the co. and Chevron (CVX) will have to invest USD 30bln in their Permian operations through 2020, according to HIS Markit. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Oil rebounds on OPEC source reports mentioning an output hike of 300k-600k bpd (vs. 1.5mln bpd touted previously)
  • The Dollar is mixed overall, but the index did revisit 95.000+ ytd peaks (around 95.150)
  • Looking ahead, highlights include comments from Fed’s Dudley, Bostic and Williams, BoC’s Deputy Governor and ECB President Draghi

 

ASIA

Asia stocks mostly backpedalled at the start of the week as the region digested the tit-for-tat trade spat between US and China, in which the US confirmed tariffs on USD 50bln of Chinese goods and China responded with reciprocal tariffs of the same value against the US. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) both opened negative with Australia initially led lower by commodity-related sectors although strength in financials and healthcare later reversed the downside in the index, while sentiment in Japan was dampened by a firmer JPY and amid a fatal earthquake in Osaka. KOSPI (-1.2%) underperformed as a fallout from the US-China tariff dispute due to fears South Korea could feel the brunt of the trade war between its 2 largest trading partners, and with index-heavyweight Samsung Electronics pressured after it was ordered to pay USD 400mln for patent infringement related to semiconductor technology. Finally, markets in mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Indonesia were all closed for holiday, while 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the risk averse tone as prices took a breather from last week’s upside and following a lack of a Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

Mofcom stated they will impose 25% tariffs on chemicals, medical equipment, energy products and chemicals, while China will also impose tariffs on US crude oil, natgas and some refined products at a later date. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY) (May) -578.3B vs. Exp. -205.2B (Prev. 626.0B, Rev. 624.6B). (Newswires)

Japanese Exports YY (May) 8.1% vs. Exp. 7.5% (Prev. 7.8%); 4-month high.

Japanese Imports YY (May) 14.0% vs. Exp. 8.2% (Prev. 5.9%)

UK/EU

British Chambers of Commerce said the UK economy looks set for its weakest growth since 2009 amid uncertainties related to Brexit, higher energy prices and trade war concerns. (Newswires)

Conservative rebels have admitted they could collapse the government if they vote against Theresa May’s final Brexit deal. (BBC)

Germany CSU party is expected to decide today whether to oppose Chancellor Merkel and implement plan which seeks to limit immigration, while reports also noted that German Chancellor Merkel is seeking crisis talks as she hopes to avert a split of the coalition government. Furthermore, there were later comments from CSU party leader Seehofer that the government situation is serious but manageable. (FT/Newswires) Reports also stated that CSU party leader Seehofer will give Merkel two weeks to gain support from EU partners on a migration agreement, or he will carry out the order himself. (Sky News/Guardian)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) M/M 0.4% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 1.7% (Prev. 1.1%)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 -1.1%) took impetus from Asia as the fallout from the US-China tariff dispute continue to subdue the market. FTSE 100 (-0.3%) outperforms its major peers as the index is kept afloat by currency effects. Broad-based losses are seen across all sectors while energy names outperform following the rebound of oil prices (following OPEC source reports that a smaller than expected output hike is to be discussed). Looking at stock specifics, Aviva (+1.6%) and RSA (+0.7%) are amongst UK’s top performers after reports that DAX 30 heavyweight Allianz (-1.0%) is considering the companies for a large UK deal. Elsewhere, Hermes (-0.4%) replaced Lafargeholcim (-0.9%) in the CAC 40 today.

FX

USD - The Dollar is mixed overall, but the index did revisit 95.000+ ytd peaks (around 95.150) forged in wake of last week’s divergent Fed and ECB policy actions/guidance in early EU trade before losing momentum as EUR and GBP regained some composure. A clearer or convincing break above the big figure would bring strong resistance just ahead of 95.500, but this may also require other G10 pairs to breach levels that have held so far, like 111.00 in Usd/Jpy and 1.3200 in Usd/Cad.

EUR/GBP - As noted, the major laggards as Eur/Usd struggles to recover from last week’s dovish ECB rate guidance, while Cable is range-bound between 1.3225-85 amidst ongoing Brexit jitters and ahead of this week’s BoE policy meeting that is widely if not unanimously expected to see the MPC stand pat again and signal no urgency to normalise policy further.

JPY/CAD -Relative outperformers with Usd/Jpy pivoting around 110.50 and the Jpy benefiting from a degree of safe-haven demand amidst the latest import tariff trade-off between the US and China, while the Loonie has recovered some lost ground to trade back above 1.3200 vs its US peer after sliding in wake of the G7 fall-out. Note, latest OPEC spec suggesting 300-600k BPD output increase has boosted crude prices and the Cad to a degree.

CHF/AUD/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the Franc holding just above parity, Aud above 0.7400 and Kiwi at 0.6900+.

TRY - Attempting to pare some of its recent losses beyond 4.7000 vs the Usd, but still looking very vulnerable against the backdrop of widespread EM weakness relative to the Dollar as Turkey’s election looms and polls indicate a very unpredictable outcome. Indeed, even improvements in the jobless rate and a swing in the budget balance to a surplus from deficit is not offering the Lira any real comfort.

FIXED INCOME

Some debt market observers and practitioners are pointing to the fact that Bunds were able to stave off a deeper set-back in early Eurex trade and defended the 161.00 line, while Gilts fended off sellers at the 122.50 level and this resilience prompted dip-buyers to chance their arm. However, this notion has more specific technical backing as the 161.02 low in the German 10 year future also closed a chart gap and the rebound achieved a bullish target around 161.31 on the way to the 161.41 peak, but with 161.48-52 not yet threatened and the upper end of that range housing last Friday’s post-ECB high. Back to Liffe, the core 10 year bond reached 122.80 before fading, and weakness in EU stocks may well be impacting too. Turning to US Treasuries, the complex is poised

close to mid-range levels between overnight session parameters and with the curve mildly flatter yet again.

COMMODITIES

Oil is extending the losses seen at the end of last week as concerns over Chinese crude tariffs hit the market. WTI is down as investors are selling the fossil fuel on this news, as well as ahead of the upcoming OPEC meetings this week that are set to announce increased production for the cartel. Brent is outperforming WTI on Libyan internal conflicts affecting refinery production.

Source reports stated that OPEC is said to discuss an output hike of 300k-600k bpd, while Saudi and Russia are said to work on making the oil alliance permanent. Furthermore, OPEC members are said to be looking for a compromise to overcome the Iran dissent. (Newswires)

Weekend reports noted that Russian Energy Minister Novak stated OPEC and non-OPEC countries will discuss raising oil output by 1.5mln bpd in Q3 only. However, Iran stated that 3 OPEC members (Iraq, Iran & Venezuela) will veto a proposed production increase. (Newswires)

In the metals scope gold is in the green (+0.2%) as market sentiment sours on Chinese trade concerns and investors are flocking to safe haven assets. Copper has slipped for the second straight session and is at USD 6,997/tonne hovering just above 2 week lows as supply concerns continue to ease. Aluminium is also falling and has hit 2 month lows at USD 2,193/tonne, with support seen at the 200dma of USD 2,175/tonne

Libya’s NOC said a fire at two storage tanks in Libya’s Ras Lanuf reduced storage capacity to 550k barrels from 950k barrels. (Newswires)

Venezuela’s PDVSA Isla refinery in Curacao is closed due to lack of crude, according to sources. (Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) says they are in talks with the supervisory board of Tata Steel (TATA IS) to get the JV done

However, Iran stated that 3 OPEC members (Iraq, Iran & Venezuela) will veto a proposed production increase. Ahead of this meeting banks are expecting production increases of 700k BPD (SocGen & Barclays) to 1mln BPD (Goldman Sachs). Sources in EU trade suggested that this would be a smaller hike than expected, however, with 300-600k BPD the stated figures.

In the metals scope gold is in the green (+0.15%) as market sentiment sours on Chinese trade concerns and investors are flocking to safe haven assets. Copper has slipped for the second straight session and is at USD 6,997/tonne hovering just above 2 week lows as supply concerns continue to ease. Aluminium is also falling and has hit 2 month lows at USD 2,193/tonne, with support seen at the 200dma of USD 2,175/tonne

Fixed Income: firm rebound in core bonds from early lows
content: Some debt market observers and practitioners are pointing to the fact that Bunds were able to stave off a deeper set-back in early Eurex trade and defended the 161.00 line, while Gilts fended off sellers at the 122.50 level and this resilience prompted dip-buyers to chance their arm. However, this notion has more specific technical backing as the 161.02 low in the German 10 year future also closed a chart gap and the rebound achieved a bullish target around 161.31 on the way to the 161.41 peak, but with 161.48-52 not yet threatened and the upper end of that range housing last Friday’s post-ECB high. Back to Liffe, the core 10 year bond reached 122.80 before fading, and weakness in EU stocks may well be impacting too. Turning to US Treasuries, the complex is poised close to mid-range levels between overnight session parameters and with the curve mildly flatter yet again.

FX Morning Colour: DXY eyeing 95.000+ peaks again, as Eur and Gbp underperform
content:
USD

The Dollar is mixed overall, but netting more gains vs the Eur and Gbp in particular against losses elsewhere to nudge the index back up to 95.000 and close to ytd peaks (around 95.150) forged in wake of last week’s divergent Fed and ECB policy actions/guidance. A clearer or convincing break above the big figure would bring strong resistance just ahead of 95.500, but this may also require other G10 pairs to breach levels that have held so far, like 111.00 in Usd/Jpy and 1.3200 in Usd/Cad.

EUR/GBP

 As noted, the major laggards as Eur/Usd remains capped ahead of 1.1600, while Cable is retreating towards 1.3200 amidst ongoing Brexit jitters and ahead of this week’s BoE policy meeting that is widely if not unanimously expected to see the MPC stand pat again and signal no urgency to normalise policy further. Nearest support is 1.3210 and for Eur/Usd the 2018 base at 1.1510.

JPY/CAD

Marginal outperformers with Usd/Jpy pivoting around 110.50 and the Jpy benefiting from a degree of safe-haven demand amidst the latest import tariff trade-off between the US and China, while the Loonie has recovered some lost ground to trade back above 1.3200 vs its US peer after sliding in wake of the G7 fall-out.

CHF/AUD/NZD

All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the Franc holding just above parity, Aud above 0.7400 and Kiwi at 0.6900+.

TRY

Attempting to pare some of its recent losses beyond 4.7000 vs the Usd, but still looking very vulnerable against the backdrop of widespread EM weakness relative to the Dollar as Turkey’s election looms and polls indicate a very unpredictable outcome. Indeed, even improvements in the jobless rate and a swing in the budget balance to a surplus from deficit is not offering the Lira any real comfort.

Monday’s UK slate is barren, so Gilts and Short Sterling are largely left to look elsewhere for impetus/direction, barring anything new on the Brexit front, and venturing a bit further ahead even Thursday’s BoE policy verdict is widely expected to reveal no changes, although the minutes and vote split will likely provide some independent price movement.

Bunds: somewhat betwixt and between
content: An indifferent start to Monday’s Eurex session with the 10 year German debt future opening pretty flat and then attempting to grind higher but losing momentum relatively quickly and slipping below par within a 161.03-22 range vs last Friday’s 161.16 close. Global trade wars are back in the spotlight after last week’s major focus on CB policy, and especially the ECB that sprang several surprises via the timing of the announcement to terminate QE at the end of December, while signalling at least a 9 month lead time from then until a rate hike. Looking ahead, President Draghi may expand further on the policy outlook at Sintra later today, but it is hard to imagine what he can add in terms of fresh guidance, while today’s data slate is sparse so Bunds could continue to consolidate off recent peaks awaiting new drivers.

18th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks mostly backpedalled at the start of the week as the region digested the tit-for-tat trade spat between US and China, in which the US confirmed tariffs on USD 50bln of Chinese goods and China responded with reciprocal tariffs of the same value against the US. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) both opened negative with Australia initially led lower by commodity-related sectors although strength in financials and healthcare later reversed the downside in the index, while sentiment in Japan was dampened by a firmer JPY and amid a fatal earthquake in Osaka. KOSPI (-1.3%) underperformed as a fallout from the US-China tariff dispute due to fears South Korea could feel the brunt of the trade war between its 2 largest trading partners, and with index-heavyweight Samsung Electronics pressured after it was ordered to pay USD 400mln for patent infringement related to semiconductor technology. Finally, markets in mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Indonesia were all closed for holiday, while 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the risk averse tone as prices took a breather from last week’s upside and following a lack of a Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian shares pressured after China retaliates to US tariffs; HK and China markets closed
  • Oil lower as Russian Energy Minister Novak proposes extension of the OPEC+ deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB President Draghi speaking at the Sintra Monetary Policy conference

 

ASIA

Asia stocks mostly backpedalled at the start of the week as the region digested the tit-for-tat trade spat between US and China, in which the US confirmed tariffs on USD 50bln of Chinese goods and China responded with reciprocal tariffs of the same value against the US. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) both opened negative with Australia initially led lower by commodity-related sectors although strength in financials and healthcare later reversed the downside in the index, while sentiment in Japan was dampened by a firmer JPY and amid a fatal earthquake in Osaka. KOSPI (-1.3%) underperformed as a fallout from the US-China tariff dispute due to fears South Korea could feel the brunt of the trade war between its 2 largest trading partners, and with index-heavyweight Samsung Electronics pressured after it was ordered to pay USD 400mln for patent infringement related to semiconductor technology. Finally, markets in mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Indonesia were all closed for holiday, while 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the risk averse tone as prices took a breather from last week’s upside and following a lack of a Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

China announced on Friday to impose USD 50bln of retaliatory tariffs on US 659 agricultural and autos goods from 6th July in response to US tariffs. Mofcom also stated they will impose 25% tariffs on chemicals, medical equipment, energy products and chemicals, while China will also impose tariffs on US crude oil, natgas and some refined products at a later date. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance Total (JPY) (May) -578.3B vs. Exp. -205.2B (Prev. 626.0B, Rev. 624.6B). (Newswires)
Japanese Exports YY (May) 8.1% vs. Exp. 7.5% (Prev. 7.8%); 4-month high.
Japanese Imports YY (May) 14.0% vs. Exp. 8.2% (Prev. 5.9%)

UK/EU

British Chambers of Commerce said the UK economy looks set for its weakest growth since 2009 amid uncertainties related to Brexit, higher energy prices and trade war concerns. (Newswires)

High import tariffs and high regulatory barriers caused by Brexit could cost the UK up to GBP 27bln, leaving households up to GBP 1000 worse off a year and supermarket business profits wiped out according to an analysis to be published next week and seen by the BBC. (BBC)
 

Conservative rebels have admitted they could collapse the government if they vote against Theresa May’s final Brexit deal. (BBC)

Irish PM Varadkar said he is not convinced there have been sufficient progress in Brexit talks yet. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) M/M 0.4% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 1.7% (Prev. 1.1%)

Germany CSU party is expected to decide today whether to oppose Chancellor Merkel and implement plan which seeks to limit immigration, while reports also noted that German Chancellor Merkel is seeking crisis talks as she hopes to avert a split of the coalition government. Furthermore, there were later comments from CSU party leader Seehofer that the government situation is serious but manageable. (FT/Newswires) Reports also stated that CSU party leader Seehofer will give Merkel two weeks to gain support from EU partners on a migration agreement, or he will carry out the order himself. (Sky News/Guardian)


Greek PM Tsipras survived a no-confidence vote on Saturday with the motion defeated through voting of 153 vs.127. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Denmark at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Ireland at A+; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Moody’s affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, USD was slightly firmer overnight as safe-haven currencies were supported from the risk averse tone and with the DXY holding on to the momentum from last week’s more hawkish Fed undertone and divergence with the ECB on rates. This weighed on its major counterparts with EUR/USD at a sub-1.1600 handle and with GBP/USD firmly below 1.3300, while commodity-linked currencies were also lacklustre amid a continued slip in oil prices and with NZD dampened by a softer growth outlook. Conversely, CHF and JPY fared better with JPY-crosses the biggest movers overnight due to the currency’s safe-haven status and after Japanese Exports data topped estimates.

New Zealand GDP growth outlook is seen softer in the near term according to NZIER consensus report, which also expects growth to peak at 3.2% for the year to March 2020 before easing to 2.9% by 2021. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre overnight in which WTI extended on Friday’s slump with another near-2% drop which prices slipped below USD 64.00/bbl. The pressure on oil comes ahead of Friday’s OPEC meeting and with producers at loggerheads regarding a touted 1.5mln bpd output increase favoured by Saudi and Russia, which Iran, Iraq and Venezuela are planning to veto. Elsewhere, gold is relatively flat as attempts to nurse Friday’s losses of around USD 20/oz was thwarted by a firm greenback, and copper remained subdued amid the risk averse tone as well as the absence of its largest consumer China.

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia and Saudi Arabia agreed OPEC+ should be institutionalised and extended to 2019 and beyond. In addition, reports also noted that Novak also stated OPEC and non-OPEC countries will discuss raising the oil output by 1.5mln bpd in Q3 only. However, Iran stated that 3 OPEC members (Iraq, Iran & Venezuela) will veto a proposed production increase. (Newswires)

Libya’s NOC said a fire at two storage tanks in Libya’s Ras Lanuf reduced storage capacity to 550k barrels from 950k barrels. (Newswires)

Venezuela’s PDVSA Isla refinery in Curacao is closed due to lack of crude, according to sources. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (15 Jun) 1059 (Prev. 1062). (Newswires)
US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (15 Jun) 863 (Prev. 862)
US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (15 Jun) 194 (Prev. 198)

US

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said Fed should be moving gradually on hikes and that he doesn't want to prejudge if the Fed should pause at neutral or not, while he also stated that near-term outlook is strong and that the base case is for three hikes in 2018. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is said to have warned President Trump of dire economic consequences and possible market collapse if China tariffs were imposed. (Fox)
